hello I'm Tom Grissom I want to tell you about a serious threat to our business a new kind of war in the store mention war in the store and every member of our sales and marketing team immediately thinks of the battle for market share the enemy mostly Philip Morris and the go build our brands at the expense of theirs that's an important battle and we're making solid progress

but there's another battle heating up that threatens our business just as much or maybe even more than the activities of our competitors and that's the war in the store is being waged by any smokers during the past several months Andy smokers have launched a campaign to push local governments or local Health boards to pass merchandising restrictions these sales restrictions are being promoted under the guise of preventing children from smoking but in fact they would severely restrict the way our

products can be promoted and sold to adults these proposals would do away with self-service sales by forcing retailers to keep cigarettes behind the counter or they would prohibit couponing in-store displays and promotions I think the effect is pretty clear retail restrictions of this type for everyone they jeopardize your ability to win the war in the store against our competitors they deprived retailers of flexibility in marketing our cigarettes

and that means lost income and lost jobs these regulations also infringe on the freedom of adult smokers to make brand choices sales restrictions have been proposed in seven states in just the past few months and we expect many other cities and states to look at the issue during the next several months

any smokers know if they can catch us off-guard if they can strike before local retailers can organize they stand a better chance of succeeding but they're not going to win this new war in the store because there's something we can do for instance when the Board of Health in Framingham Massachusetts proposed a harsh new code that would have banned all freestanding cigarette displays smokers r.j.
